DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Lumpectomy Surgical Margin Excision Performed Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator surgical removal of the edge or border of a site of lumpectomy, the removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor, was performed.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Lumpectomy Surgical Margin Excision Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to surgical removal of the edge or border of a site of lumpectomy, the removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor, as the surgical procedure being performed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: The removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor. Usually some of the lymph nodes under the arm are also taken out.  Also called segmental mastectomy.:The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.:Removal or excision by surgical measures.:Performed; carried out.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a discrete mass.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.
